newIncidents.title: Trump vows voter ID requirements 'whether approved by Congress or not'
newIncidents.description: President publicly declares intent to unilaterally impose federal election requirements without congressional authorization, explicitly defying separation of powers for midterm elections. Source

newIncidents.title: Journalist Don Lemon prosecuted for ICE protest coverage
newIncidents.description: DOJ charges journalist with criminal offenses related to First Amendment-protected reporting on immigration enforcement, pleads not guilty. Source

newIncidents.title: White House fires U.S. attorney hours after judicial appointment
newIncidents.description: Administration immediately terminates U.S. attorney selected by judges to replace Trump appointee, circumventing established judicial appointment process. Source

newIncidents.title: DOJ attempts to indict six congressional Democrats
newIncidents.description: Administration seeks criminal charges against opposition lawmakers for protected speech, prompting legal action from Rep. Crow over unprecedented weaponization of DOJ. Source

newIncidents.title: Trump directs intelligence agencies to support 'Stop the Steal' lawyer
newIncidents.description: President instructs spy agencies to provide intelligence to attorney involved in partisan election challenge efforts, politicizing intelligence community. Source

newCheckEvents.text: DOJ moves to erase Steve Bannon's conviction for defying Jan. 6 congressional subpoena. Source

newTickerItems.text: Trump directs spy agencies to support 'Stop the Steal' lawyer

updates.summary: Multiple unprecedented institutional breaches recorded: Trump explicitly declared intent to impose election requirements without congressional approval, DOJ prosecuted journalist Don Lemon for protest coverage, and the administration attempted to indict six Democratic lawmakers. Additional developments include directing intelligence agencies to support partisan legal efforts, DOJ dismissing Bannon's contempt conviction, and immediate firing of a judicially-appointed U.S. attorney.
